Row.Text: I, Jamukha, welcome you to the Steppe, it's towering peaks and rolling valleys are the home of my people. Kneel before me and you shall see peace and prosperity, oppose and let your herds and families come to ruin.
You are met by the chief of the Jadaran and khan of all Mongols, Jamukha! Tengri has guided your steeds here, and I hope for your clan that he intends a great friendship rather than a tragic tale.
Now you're Khan and I'm at your feet. Are you happy?
I ask you to leave my precence for now.
Rightfully, I should demand your side of this offer and keep my own!
Say what is needed, and that alone.
Aha my friend! Come, have a seat and some Airag.
My men stand by their steeds. Do not begin to falter or we may just find what remains of your lands fine takings.
I wish the best for your people in these dangerous and stormy times.
I hope those men of yours are a hunting party. Their proximity to my lands is worrying.
The steppe belongs to the Mongol people. Your adamant claiming of it offends the lord Tengri.
My chiefs are expressing distaste at your border expansion. I suggest you stop or there may be repercussions.
I did not imagine a day when your people would foolishly settle the land of mine. Let it be known that your subjugation is all but assured.
These are the lands of my peoples. I suggest you settle elsewhere.
Your warriors are strong and numerous! Say we take them and mine to carve out greater territories?
Of all the riches on the step, yours are the greatest. I hope you will share that prosperity with my people in goodwill.
Oh look. The puny city-state yet to be annexed.
It would not surprise me if my horse we able to take out your army, without myself on its back.
You take many lands, But you are without honour. I hope Tengri brings winters of death and summers of drought upon you.
You should know my trust, while like iron, is hard to win. You have not won it yet.
You are a son of a dog and a leper. Tengri has forsaken you and so should the world. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])
Any trust I may have had is broken. May you rot in a latrine pit and men piss from above. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])
If that is how it must be, so be it.
You and {1_CivName} have much alike. You are both like siblings to me, a bond beyond blood.
{1_CivName} is a mangy hound, getting close only pushes you away from the likes of the Khamug.
The Mongols respect {1_CivName}. To get on their bad side is to see my armies at your doors.
I agree, {1_CivName} is not to be trusted.
You see {1_CivName} as a worthy friend? Then so shall I!
I see the honourless cur has a pet. Now I have to deal with both you and {1_CivName}?
I too see that {1_CivName} is without honour. The combination of our denouncements will have them rethink their actions.
The Mongols see your people have much honour. Come and stand beside us.
I have seen your feats and loyalty to your people and the lord Tengri. Shall you join us in friendship>
Move your men or they will become the target dummies for ours.
I advise you to not expand there.
Your expansion into the land of my people must stop.
Your expansion into the land of my people must stop.
Return your people home and abandon this land, before I have to ride my horses upon you.
The Khamug Mongols are eternally grateful! Tengri truely acts through you.
{2_MajorCivName:textkey} announces to the world that it is now protecting {1_MinorCivName:textkey}. Attacking the City-State will greatly damage relations and may lead to war.
{2_MajorCivName:textkey} has taken back its guarantee of protecting {1_MinorCivName:textkey}.
No. I will continue to claim the land that is mine.
An agreement is made, that land is yours.
Trade back and forth will benefit us both.
My lands are yours to wander, so long as the return is exchanged.
The Mongol people are in need, a small gift from a friend to a friend is surely not too much to offer.
There will be war, but you shall not see the Mongols fall. Our hooves will thunder against you.
I want to ask you: All Mongols fear the thunder... but not you?
The steppes will never be yours.
Tengri will see justice brought, until then it is my duty.
Ha! I do not give up so soon.
This is saddening to hear.
You have our thanks.
